definition:
(also known as [*Euler’s formula*]{}) is considered the first between
the fields of algebra and geometry, as it relates the exponential
function to the trigonometric sine and cosine functions.

Euler’s relation states that $$e^{ix} = \cos{x}+i\sin{x}$$

Start by noting that $$i^k=\begin{cases} 
1 & \mbox{if\; } k\equiv 0\!\!\pmod 4\\
i & \mbox{if\; } k\equiv 1\!\!\pmod 4\\
-1 & \mbox{if\; } k\equiv 2\!\!\pmod 4\\
-i & \mbox{if\; } k\equiv 3\!\!\pmod 4
\end{cases}$$

Using the Taylor series expansions of $e^x$, $\sin x$ and $\cos x$ (see
the entries on the complex exponential function and the complex sine and
cosine), it follows that $$\begin{aligned}
e^{ix} & = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{i^n x^n}{n!}\\
& = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{x^{4n}}{(4n)!}+
\frac{ix^{4n+1}}{(4n+1)!}
-\frac{x^{4n+2}}{(4n+2)!}-\frac{ix^{4n+3}}{(4n+3)!}\right)\end{aligned}$$
Because the series expansion above is absolutely convergent for all $x$,
we can rearrange the terms of the series as $$\begin{aligned}
e^{ix} &=  \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} (-1)^n\frac{x^{2n}}{(2n)!}+
i\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} (-1)^n\frac{x^{2n+1}}{(2n+1)!}\\
&= \cos{x}+i\sin{x}\end{aligned}$$

As a special case, we get the beautiful and well-known identity, often
called *Euler’s identity*: $$e^{i\pi}=-1$$
